column18: Given this crude approach we can assign all species - I have added my estimates for all species

I would be very surprised if great shearwaters couldn’t dive quite a bit deeper, because the other Ardenna spp. are proficient divers and usually diving ability scales positively with body mass. Also, the low values for depth and duration in Ronconi et al. might well relate to the very small sample size (just two birds). For those reasons could perhaps justify an upgrade to a dive score of 3.

column21: (1) 2m seems really quite deep for a kittiwake, as other gulls are poor divers. Hence maybe that old observational study isn’t representative and could consider dropping their dive score to 0. (2) Same applies to Greater Crested Tern, as do they really dive routinely deeper than a surface-plunging sandwich tern? (3) I would be very surprised if great shearwaters couldn’t dive quite a bit deeper, because the other Ardenna spp. are proficient divers and usually diving ability scales positively with body mass. Also, the low values for depth and duration in Ronconi et al. might well relate to the very small sample size (just two birds). For those reasons could perhaps justify an upgrade to a dive score of 3. Also, (4) I would go ahead and delete that highlighted 188s dive for a black-footed albatross as it has to be a recording error.
